\paragraph{lysis.util.kiss module}
\label{\detokenize{lysis.util:module-lysis.util.kiss}}\label{\detokenize{lysis.util:lysis-util-kiss-module}}\index{module@\spxentry{module}!lysis.util.kiss@\spxentry{lysis.util.kiss}}\index{lysis.util.kiss@\spxentry{lysis.util.kiss}!module@\spxentry{module}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Minimal skeleton for using the Marsaglia KISS generator

\sphinxAtStartPar
Wrapper for C module.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Example Usage:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} \begin{description}
\sphinxlineitem{Initialize}
\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]

\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{kiss}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{seed}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{123}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\end{description}

\item {} \begin{description}
\sphinxlineitem{Generate random integer 0..(2\textasciicircum{}32)\sphinxhyphen{}1}
\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{kiss}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{kiss32}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\end{description}

\item {} \begin{description}
\sphinxlineitem{Generate random U{[}0,1{]}}
\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{kiss}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{random}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\end{description}

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Returns the next 32\sphinxhyphen{}bit unsigned integer from the pseudo\sphinxhyphen{}random
number stream. This is distributed uniformly from 0 through (2\textasciicircum{}32)\sphinxhyphen{}1.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mscw() (lysis.util.kiss.KissRandomGenerator method)@\spxentry{mscw()}\spxextra{lysis.util.kiss.KissRandomGenerator method}}

\begin{fulllineitems}

\pysigstartsignatures
\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{mscw}}}{}{{ $\rightarrow$ int}}
\pysigstopsignatures
\sphinxAtStartPar
Returns a pseudo\sphinxhyphen{}random 32\sphinxhyphen{}bit unsigned integer
(i.e., {[}0..(2\textasciicircum{}32)\sphinxhyphen{}1{]}).
This is based on the system clock and NOT the current seed or state.

\end{fulllineitems}

\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\sphinxlineitem{Parameters}
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{seed}} \textendash{} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
The seed.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Note: While Python will accept any 64\sphinxhyphen{}bit integer
(\sphinxhyphen{}9,223,372,036,854,775,806 through 9,223,372,036,854,775,807),
this will be converted to an unsigned 32\sphinxhyphen{}bit integer (0 through
4,294,967,295) when passed to the underlying C code with
unpredictable results.


\end{description}\end{quote}

\paragraph{lysis.util.parameters module}
\label{\detokenize{lysis.util:module-lysis.util.parameters}}\label{\detokenize{lysis.util:lysis-util-parameters-module}}\index{module@\spxentry{module}!lysis.util.parameters@\spxentry{lysis.util.parameters}}\index{lysis.util.parameters@\spxentry{lysis.util.parameters}!module@\spxentry{module}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Code for holding, storing, and reading information about an experiment

\sphinxAtStartPar
This module gives a uniform way to handle the data and parameters of a given
experiment. It contains classes to house these and make them accessible to the
rest of the code. It also handles the storing and reading of parameters and
data to/from disk.
\begin{description}
\sphinxlineitem{Typical usage example:}
\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Create a new experiment}
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{exp} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{Experiment}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{path/to/data}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{param} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{override\PYGZus{}parameter}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+m+mf}{2.54}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{another\PYGZus{}new\PYGZus{}parameter}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+m+mi}{32}\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{exp}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{initialize\PYGZus{}macro\PYGZus{}param}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{param}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{exp}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{to\PYGZus{}file}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Load an existing experiment}
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{exp} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{Experiment}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{path/to/data}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{2022\PYGZus{}12\PYGZus{}27\PYGZus{}1100}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{exp}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{read\PYGZus{}file}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Access a parameter}
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{exp}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{macro\PYGZus{}params}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{pore\PYGZus{}size}
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Access data}
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{exp}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{data}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{lysis\PYGZus{}time}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{l+m+mi}{4}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{l+m+mi}{18}\PYG{p}{]}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\end{description}
\index{Experiment (class in lysis.util.parameters)@\spxentry{Experiment}\spxextra{class in lysis.util.parameters}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{lysis.util:lysis.util.parameters.Experiment}}
\pysigstartsignatures
\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{class\DUrole{w}{ }}}\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lysis.util.parameters.}}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{Experiment}}}{\sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{data\_root}\DUrole{p}{:}\DUrole{w}{ }\DUrole{n}{str\DUrole{w}{ }\DUrole{p}{|}\DUrole{w}{ }bytes\DUrole{w}{ }\DUrole{p}{|}\DUrole{w}{ }PathLike}}\sphinxparamcomma \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{experiment\_code}\DUrole{p}{:}\DUrole{w}{ }\DUrole{n}{str\DUrole{w}{ }\DUrole{p}{|}\DUrole{w}{ }None}\DUrole{w}{ }\DUrole{o}{=}\DUrole{w}{ }\DUrole{default_value}{None}}}{}
\pysigstopsignatures
\sphinxAtStartPar
Bases: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{object}}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Houses all information about a given experimental run.

\sphinxAtStartPar
This object contains:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Data location

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Experiment parameters

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Experiment data

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
It includes methods for
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Initializing with default parameters

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Reading parameters from disk

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Saving parameters to disk

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Reading input data from disk

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Writing result data to disk

\end{itemize}
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\sphinxlineitem{Parameters}\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{data\_root}} \textendash{} The path of the folder containing datasets

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{experiment\_code}} \textendash{} The code number of the experiment.
This will be the name of the folder containing the data specific to
this experiment.
This should be a date and time in ‘YYYY\sphinxhyphen{}MM\sphinxhyphen{}DD\sphinxhyphen{}hhmm’ format
If no code is given, one will be generated from the current date
and time.

\end{itemize}

\end{description}\end{quote}

\sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{macro\_version: str = \textquotesingle{}diffuse\_into\_and\_along\textquotesingle{}}}\sphinxparamcomma \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{log\_lvl: int = 30}}\sphinxparamcomma \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{duplicate\_fortran: bool = False}}\sphinxparamcomma \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{processing\_library: str = \textquotesingle{}numpy\textquotesingle{}}}}{}
\pysigstopsignatures
\sphinxAtStartPar
Bases: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{object}}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Contains parameters for the Macroscale model.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Parameters can be accessed as attributes.
Independent parameters should only be set at initialization.
Dependent parameters should never be set manually, but are automatically
calculated by internal code.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Should only be used inside an Experiment object.
\subsubsection*{Example}

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Initialize using the default values}
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{macro\PYGZus{}params\PYGZus{}default} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{MacroParameters}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Get parameter value}
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{macro\PYGZus{}params\PYGZus{}default}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{pore\PYGZus{}size}
\PYG{g+go}{1.0135e\PYGZhy{}4}
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Initialize overriding some default values}
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{p} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{binding\PYGZus{}rate}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+m+mi}{10}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{pore\PYGZus{}size}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+m+mi}{3}\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{macro\PYGZus{}params\PYGZus{}override} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{MacroParameters}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{o}{*}\PYG{o}{*}\PYG{n}{p}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}
\index{average\_bound\_time (lysis.util.parameters.MacroParameters attribute)@\spxentry{average\_bound\_time}\spxextra{lysis.util.parameters.MacroParameters attribute}}

\begin{fulllineitems}

\index{duplicate\_fortran (lysis.util.parameters.MacroParameters attribute)@\spxentry{duplicate\_fortran}\spxextra{lysis.util.parameters.MacroParameters attribute}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{lysis.util:lysis.util.parameters.MacroParameters.duplicate_fortran}}
\pysigstartsignatures
\pysigline{\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{duplicate\_fortran}}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{\DUrole{p}{:}\DUrole{w}{ }bool}}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{\DUrole{w}{ }\DUrole{p}{=}\DUrole{w}{ }False}}}
\pysigstopsignatures
\sphinxAtStartPar
Whether the Python code should follow the Fortran code step\sphinxhyphen{}by\sphinxhyphen{}step.
Theoretically, with this set to “True”, both sets of code will produce the
exact same output.
This will impact performance negatively.
This currently does nothing.
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\sphinxlineitem{Units}
\sphinxAtStartPar
None

\sphinxlineitem{Fortran}
\sphinxAtStartPar
None

\end{description}\end{quote}

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{empty\_edges (lysis.util.parameters.MacroParameters attribute)@\spxentry{empty\_edges}\spxextra{lysis.util.parameters.MacroParameters attribute}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{lysis.util:lysis.util.parameters.MacroParameters.empty_edges}}
\pysigstartsignatures

\pysigstopsignatures
\sphinxAtStartPar
The number of edges without fibrin.
Also the 1\sphinxhyphen{}D index of the last edge without fibrin when 1\sphinxhyphen{}indexing

\sphinxAtStartPar
This is probably unnecessary when using a 2\sphinxhyphen{}D data structure, but is kept
for historical reasons.

\sphinxAtStartPar
None

\sphinxlineitem{Fortran}

enoFB

\end{description}\end{quote}

\index{empty\_rows (lysis.util.parameters.MacroParameters attribute)@\spxentry{empty\_rows}\spxextra{lysis.util.parameters.MacroParameters attribute}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{lysis.util:lysis.util.parameters.MacroParameters.empty_rows}}
\pysigstartsignatures
\pysigline{\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{empty\_rows}}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{\DUrole{p}{:}\DUrole{w}{ }int}}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{\DUrole{w}{ }\DUrole{p}{=}\DUrole{w}{ }28}}}
\pysigstopsignatures
\sphinxAtStartPar
The number of fibrin\sphinxhyphen{}free rows at the top of the grid.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Equivalent to ‘first\_fiber\_row’, which is the 1st node in vertical
direction containing fibers.
So if first\_fiber\_row = 10, then rows 0\sphinxhyphen{}9 have no fibers, there’s one more
row of fiber\sphinxhyphen{}free planar vertical edges, and then the row with index
‘first\_fiber\_row’ (e.g. 11th) is a full row of fibers.
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\sphinxlineitem{Units}
\sphinxAtStartPar
None

\sphinxlineitem{Fortran}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Ffree\sphinxhyphen{}1

\end{description}\end{quote}

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{fortran\_names() (lysis.util.parameters.MacroParameters static method)@\spxentry{fortran\_names()}\spxextra{lysis.util.parameters.MacroParameters static method}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{lysis.util:lysis.util.parameters.MacroParameters.fortran_names}}
\pysigstartsignatures
\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{static\DUrole{w}{ }}}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{fortran\_names}}}{}{}
\pysigstopsignatures
\sphinxAtStartPar
Returns a dictionary whose keys are the names of all parameters (both micro\sphinxhyphen{} and macroscale)
that have equivalents in Fortran. The values in the dictionary are the names of the equivalent
Fortran variable names.
These values are parsed from the docstrings in this file.

\end{fulllineitems}

\sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{\textquotesingle{}1 / second\textquotesingle{})\textgreater{}}}\sphinxparamcomma \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{exposure\_rate\_binding\_site: \textasciitilde{}pint.registry.Quantity = \textless{}Quantity(5.0}}\sphinxparamcomma \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{\textquotesingle{}1 / second\textquotesingle{})\textgreater{}}}\sphinxparamcomma \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{nodes\_in\_row: int = 7}}\sphinxparamcomma \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{snap\_proportion: float = 0.6666666666666666}}\sphinxparamcomma \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{simulations: int = 50000}}\sphinxparamcomma \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{seed: int = 0}}\sphinxparamcomma \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{micro\_version: str = \textquotesingle{}micro\_rates\textquotesingle{}}}\sphinxparamcomma \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{log\_lvl: int = 30}}}{}
\pysigstopsignatures
\sphinxAtStartPar
Bases: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{object}}

\sphinxAtStartPar
This will contain the parameters for the Microscale model.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Parameters can be accessed as attributes.
Independent parameters should only be set at initialization.
Dependent parameters should never be set manually, but are automatically
calculated by internal code.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Should only be used inside an Experiment object.
\subsubsection*{Example}

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Initialize using the default values}
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{micro\PYGZus{}params\PYGZus{}default} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{MicroParameters}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Get parameter value}
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{micro\PYGZus{}params\PYGZus{}default}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{fibrinogen\PYGZus{}length}
\PYG{g+go}{45 nanometers}
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Initialize overriding some default values}

Fortran variable names.

\begin{fulllineitems}

\pysigstopsignatures
\sphinxAtStartPar
Returns a dictionary whose keys are the names of all parameters (both micro\sphinxhyphen{} and macroscale)
that have units. The values in the dictionary are those units.
These values are parsed from the docstrings in this file.
